body.p:
Louisville Jany 11th 1861.
Hon. B. Magoffin
Dr Sir.

At the last Term of the Criminal Court for Jefferson county Charles Hawkins was tried & convicted & Sentenced to two years confinement in the Penatentiary for Malicious stabbing of Thomas Murray. The conviction of Hawkins was on the Testimony of Murray; Wm Brown & Jno Koenig. I have learned that Murray & Brown have made an affidavit which with a Petition from the Widowed Mother of Hawkins for his Pardon will be laid before you; I know the man Koenig he has been twice before me on the charge of Pettit Larceny once before he Testified in the case against Hawkins & ever since & on both occasions his guilt was clearly Established his Statement is entitled to no credit that his character been Known to the Jury I am certain they would have given no credit to his statements From facts which have transpired since the Trial of Hawkins I beleive he should be Pardoned he is poor, his mother a widow & without means they were unable to make such a defense as under other circumstances might have been made. I
Have not seen the affidavit made by Murray & Brown but understand they make statements now varrying Materially the Evidence given by them to the Jury & which if made then would have Insured his acquittal. hoping you may be satisfied that the young ^man^ has been unfairly dealt by on the part of the Witnesses in giveing their testimony & that he is entitled to a discharge

I remain Dr Sir
Your friend
Geo. W. Johnston.
In consideration of the Youth of Hawkins and the anxiety of his friends, and a retraction to some extent of the statements of some of the witnesses in the case I Join in his petition
E S Craig Atto for Com^th^ 7th Ju Dis
